mainContent.text: About This Process

Your accessibility statement helps everybody, particularly disabled students. You will be asked to respond to a series of statements to confirm your inclusive practices. If selected, your answers will be shown to all students enrolled on this module.
Benefits to Students and Staff
For students with accessibility requirements or specific learning difficulties, the statement provides:

items: Clarity on what to expect from your module
Confidence in the University's commitment to accessibility
Reduced fear for disclosure and requesting adjustments

mainContent.text: For teaching staff, the statement:

items: Helps ensure you've considered key accessibility requirements
Provides a tool for reflection and improvement
Demonstrates your commitment to inclusive teaching
Helps you meet university policy requirements

mainContent.text: What This Statement Tells You

This statement explains the specific steps your teaching team has taken to make this module accessible and inclusive for all students, including those with disabilities or specific learning differences.
Why Accessibility Matters

Digital accessibility is about creating content everyone can use. This includes students with visual, hearing, physical, cognitive, neurological or learning disabilities. Accessible content benefits all students, particularly those learning in different environments.

statement1.title: Supporting student accessibility
statement1.question: I review the list of students who have Student Support Recommendations (SSRs) on my module and review the recommended reasonable adjustments. The module teaching team implements recommended adjustments where it is possible to do so. Where an adjustment is not possible to implement, I discuss alternatives with the Student Disability and Inclusion Team.

additionalLink.text: Link to view Student Support Recommendations

mainContent.text: An inclusive experience

The module teaching team have committed to reviewing any reasonable adjustments recommended by the Student Disability and Inclusion Team for this module. Where an adjustment is not feasible to implement, module leads will review with the Student Disability and Inclusion Team.

statement2.title: Microsoft Accessibility checks
statement2.question: When I create new module content or update existing module content, where possible I check that it passes the Microsoft Accessibility Checks and act on accessibility feedback given through Blackboard's accessibility score.

mainContent.text: Accessible content
The module team makes new and updated content easier for everyone to use:

items: We use tools like Office Accessibility Assistant and Blackboard Ally to check if our new and updated content works well for all students.
Our team fixes problems these tools find.
This means you should be able to use the content easily, whether you're using assistive tech or need it in a different format.

mainContent.text: Be aware:

items: Some older content or pieces we've borrowed from elsewhere might still be tricky to access.
You can find out more about how digitally accessible your module is later in this statement.

statement3.title: Blackboard curation
statement3.question: Content I add into this Blackboard module is contextualised, explaining why this item is included and an indication as to what students should do with it. Files are named consistently and meaningfully.

mainContent.text: Example of contextualised content:

items: "Watch this supplementary video if you are struggling with this particular technique".
"Ahead of the lecture, read through this problem statement, make notes and prepare to ask questions on this topic".

mainContent.text: Example of consistent and meaningful file names:

items: "Week 3 Lecture Notes- Electricity and Electronics (Circuit Theory 3) -GENG1234.pptx"
"Week 5 - Media Effects Theory – FILM1234.pptx"
"Module Handbook 2025-26 – CHEM1234.docx"

mainContent.text: Organising module content
We've made your Blackboard module clear and easy to follow. Here's how we help you stay organised:
Finding Your Way Around
Everything we put on this Blackboard module has a clear purpose. You'll always know:

items: What it is.
Why it's useful for you.
What you need to do with it.

mainContent.text: Clear Signposts
We give you helpful hints like:
"Having trouble with this technique? Watch this extra video to help you understand".
"Before your next class: Take a look at this problem and write down any questions you have".
Easy-to-Find Files
We name all files in a way that makes sense. This helps you:

items: Find things quickly.
Know what's inside each file.
Stay organised when revising.

mainContent.text: Examples of File Names
Your files will look like this:

items: Week 3 Lecture Notes - Electricity & Electronics (Circuit Theory 3) - GENG1234.pptx
Week 5 - Media Effects Theory - FILM1234.pptx
Module Handbook 2025-26 - CHEM1234.docx

statement4.title: Assessment Details Made Clear
statement4.question: The assessment section of the Blackboard module includes a clear breakdown of the weighting for the module and a sub-section for each assessment which states whether it is formative or summative and includes the assessment brief, instructions and mark scheme or rubric.

mainContent.text: Understanding Your Assessments
Within the assessments area of your Blackboard module, each piece of work you will be asked to complete will have its own section. You'll find:

items: Whether it counts towards your final mark and how much the assignment contributes to your final mark.
Clear instructions about what to do.
An assignment rubric that set out exactly what we're looking for in your work and how we will mark it.

statement5.title: Reading lists
statement5.question: This module has an online reading list. Within the online reading list, all items are labelled "essential" or "additional" to indicate their importance. Where required, resources have been digitised by the Library and made available in the reading list. Therefore, I have not uploaded copyrighted material in my Blackboard module.

mainContent.text: Reading List: Your Path, Your Pace
This module has an online reading list. The library's online reading list gives you easy and direct access to the books, journal articles and other resources connected to your module.
The module leads have indicated the importance of each resource as either "essential" (core, must read resources) or "additional" (recommended and further reading).

statement6.title: Additional Information
statement6.question: Do you wish to share with the students enrolled on this module other steps you have you taken or wish to take to make your Blackboard module accessible and inclusive? Your answer will be displayed to students within the module accessibility statement. Do not share any confidential, personal or identifying information, particularly about disabled students on your module.

mainContent.text: A message from your module lead
Example sample statements:

items: "I have worked with a Learning Designer to resolve severe accessibility issues and am planning further improvement over the next 12 months".
"I have worked with course reps / responded to course rep feedback from Student Staff Liaison Committees to make improvements to the module."
"I have worked with several students with dyslexia to improve the presentation and structure of my slide decks".
"I have restructured the reading list and removed scanned documents from this course. The Library Digitisation Unit have created high quality versions which are in the reading list".
"During the summer I engaged the services of Digital Learning's Accessibility Allies who helped me to make more accessible content such as adding alternative text to images in my course".
